text.0: what dearest pair is this in strength and riches that ye as priests are bring from the waters.
text.1: this sacrifice is your glorification ye who protect mankind and give them treasures.
text.2: may your pure steeds raindrinkers bring you hither swift as the tempest your celestial coursers.
text.3: rapid as thought with fair backs full of vigour resplendent in their native light o aśvins.
text.4: your car is like a torrent rushing downward may it come nigh broadseated for our welfare.
text.5: car holy strong that ever would be foremost thoughtswift which ye for whom we long have mounted.
text.6: here sprung to life they both have sung together with bodies free from stain with signs that mark them.
text.7: one of you prince of sacrifice the victor the other counts as heavens auspicious offspring.
text.8: may your carseat downgliding goldencoloured according to your wish approach our dwellings.
text.9: men shall feed full the bay steeds of the other and aśvins they with roars shall stir the regions.
text.10: forth comes your strong bull like a cloud of autumn sending abundant food of liquid sweetness.
text.11: let them feed with the others ways and vigour the upper streams have come and do us service.
text.12: your constant song hath been sent forth disposers that flows threefold in mighty strength o aśvins.
text.13: thus lauded give the suppliant protection moving or resting hear mine invocation.
text.14: this song of bright contents for you is swelling in the mens hall where threefold grass is ready.
text.15: your strong raincloud ye mighty ones hath swollen honouring men as twere with milks outpouring.
text.16: the prudent worshipper like pūṣan aśvins praises you as he praises dawn and agni.
text.17: when singing with devotion he invokes you may we find strengthening food in full abundance.
